SINGAPORE

LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY DEBATES

OFFICIAL REPORT

THIRD SESSION OF THE FIRST LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY

FIRST SERIES
VOLUME 9
PART IV OF SESSION 1958-9

Column: 1889

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

LOCAL GOVERNMENT
ELECTIONS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question-[26th January, 1959]:

    "That the Bill be now read the Third time."

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, continuing my speech made yesterday, I wish to give the first reason why I advocate compulsory voting. It is because I believe that compulsory voting would rectify the not fully representative nature of Government, which arises from optional voting.

    Sir, as an ironical example, there is the so-called popularly elected City Council in Singapore. Here is a news cutting from the Sunday Times of 22nd December, 1957.

    "The People's Action Party have 13 seats; the Liberal Socialist Party have seven seats; the Labour Front - four seats; Workers' Party - four seats; UMNO - two seats; and Independents - two seats."

    I beg your pardon for having to bring out the names of the particular wards from which the candidates were returned. But it will show and prove to the House what type of City Council we have today. Does it really fully represent the wishes of the people? Do the Councillors really gain popular support?

    People these days are very busy and they tend to forget the past quickly. Therefore, it would be nice if I were to bring back their memories.

    Mr Wee Swee Hong (Liberal Socialist Party) was returned in the Aljunied Ward with a percentage of 27.3 per cent of the total votes polled; Mr John Mammen (P.A.P.). (Member for Anson), 33.3 per cent; Mr Sze Lih Hwa (P.A.P.). Member for Bras Basah, 32.3 per cent; Mr G. Govindasamy (Independent), Member for Bukit Merah, 21.1 per cent; Mr O. S. Rengasamy (Workers' Party), Member for Cairnhill, 29.4 per cent; Inche Baharudin Bin

Column: 1890

Mohamed Ariff (P.A.P.), Member for Crawford, 42.11 per cent; Mr J. C. Corera (Workers' Party), Member for Delta, 37.1 per cent; Mr N. Karuppiah (Independent), Member for Farrer Park, 33 per cent; Mr Kum Teng Hock (P.A.P.), Member for Geylang East, 33.2 per cent; Mr Low Por Tuck (P.A.P.), Member for Geylang West, 41.5 per cent; Mr Lee Hwee Yiow (Labour Front), Member for Havelock, 35.6 per cent; Mr Ong Eng Guan (P.A.P.), Member for Hong Lim, who is now our Mayor, 36.4 per cent; Mr Chan Chee Seng (P.A.P.), Member for Jalan Besar, 34.9 per cent; Mr Chang Yuen Tong (Workers' Party), Member for Kallang, 46.3 per cent; Madam Hoe Puay Choo (P.A.P.), Member for Kampong Glam, 38.3 per cent; Mr Wee Toon Boon (P.A.P.), Member for Kampong Kapor, 39.4 per cent; Miss Chan Choy Siong (P.A.P.), Member for Kreta Ayer, 15.5 per cent; Mr Lim Choo Sye (Liberal Socialist Party), Member for Moulmein, 28.1 per cent; Our heroine of the City Council, Mrs Felice Leon-Soh (Liberal Socialist Party), Member for Mountbatten, 24.6 per cent. Now she is leading the Katong Council or something like that.

    Mr Ong Say Yeo (Liberal Socialist Party). Member for Pasir Panjang, 39.7 per cent; Mr Tang Peng Yeu (Labour Front), Member for Queenstown, 33.2 per cent.

    Mr William Tan rose -

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    Mr William Tan: Sir, is the Member allowed to read out the results of the last election? He is taking up the time of the hon. Members in this House.

    Mr Speaker: I do not know what the point of order is. But I think the hon. Member is perfectly in order if he wishes to inform the hon. Members of the results of the City Council election.

    Mr William Tan: Sir, it is quite a lengthy result. We all know the results of the last election. He need not waste our time.

    Mr Speaker: It is not a point of order. Mr Lim Cher Kheng.

Column: 1891



    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Well, well, that is the type of Assemblymen we have -

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, if the hon. Member for Tiong Bahru is so impatient, he can go out and have a-

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: All right, Sir, I beg your pardon. Now, I come back to the results.

    Mr Ho Kok Hoe (Labour Front), Member for River Valley, 28.18 per cent; Mr Lin You Eng (P.A.P.), Member for Rochore, 41.1 per cent; Mr S. M. Vasagar (Liberal-Socialist Party), Member for Sepoy Lines, 35.9 per cent; Mr G. B. Armstrong (Labour Front), Member for Stamford, 15.78 per cent; Inche Mohamed Shariff bin Dollah (UMNO), Member for Tanglin, 25.1 per cent; Mr Ong Pang Boon (P.A.P.), Member for Tanjong Pagar, 32.2 per cent; Mr Wang Tsun Hao (Workers' Party), Member for Telok Ayer, 47.9 per cent; Inche Syed Ali Redha Alsagoff (UMNO), Member for Telok Blangah, 37.2 per cent; Mr Lee Bah Chee (Liberal-Socialist Party), Member for Tiong Bahru, who is the friend of our hon. Member for Tiong Bahru, was returned with the marvellous result of 32.4 per cent; Mr Wong Soon Fong (P.A.P.), Member for Toa Payoh, 42.1 per cent; Mr Chua Kim Kee (Liberal-Socialist Party), Member for Ulu Pandan, 33.2 per cent.

    Sir, I am sorry to have taken up so much valuable time of the Assembly, especially of the Member for Tiong Bahru. But the point I would like to emphasise is that these election results give an ironical proof that we have to rectify the not fully representative nature of a Government or any authority which arises from optional voting. We are going to get this kind of result if we say to the people, "You can go or you can stay at home."

    There is one sad thing in the Singapore City Council affairs. The debate that is going on in the City Council, whether it is on a big thing or a small matter, is so well-known that it may be known all over the world by now. Regarding

Column: 1892

the decisions made by the City Council, are they fully and popularly supported by the people?

    These City Councillors were returned on a small margin of votes polled, some as low as 15 per cent. Where were those 85 per cent voters? Where was their voice? What was their stand? Do they approve every action taken and every issue raised in the City Council?

    Therefore, any decision or legislation passed will not represent the wishes of the people as a whole, unless all the eligible voters take part in it. Then will the democratic process be secured.

    The second reason why I support compulsory voting is that I believe it would bring to the polls many voters who are in favour of a stable form of government. The right of suffrage and democracy can be preserved only through the exercise of that right. Are the people of Singapore fully aware of our political aspirations?

    From time to time I have been confronted by foreign visitors and they seem to think that our political status is rather peculiar. They say that we are not a Colony because we are going to have a Head of State (maybe we will have to address him as His Majesty the Yang di-Pertuan Negara), and yet we are under the control of the Colonial Office in London. Therefore, we are neither a Colony nor an independent state. Why has Singapore been thrown into such a peculiar situation? I wonder how many people know this exactly.

    From time to time I have not only advocated a merger, which is popularly supported by our Chief Minister, Tun Lim Yew Hock, or even our most respected-

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member should stop at "Chief Minister", and not give him a name.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Even if these two nationalist leaders, our Chief Minister and the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, decide on a merger, I do not think Whitehall or even the White House will allow Singapore and Malaya to merge so easily. It is because Singapore has been outlined as a

Column: 1893

most important strategic port by the Western bloc. They just do not trust the people of Malaya and Singapore. In this respect, I would like to recall the remarks I made in this House about two years ago. We must think this: without Gen. Tojo in Japan and Hitler in Germany, I do not think we will ever have this so-called constitutional advancement or a Rendel Constitution even. In other words, Sir, -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I am just wondering how Gen. Tojo has anything to do with compulsory voting in Singapore. Perhaps the hon. Member would like to relate Gen. Tojo to compulsory voting?

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, we cannot afford to have any radical change. If there is any radical change we must wait for the whole of Asia or the whole world to have a change. Therefore, we need a moderate and stable Government. We do not want any pink party (not red but pink). They try to mislead the masses. They want to have land reforms; they want to "down with the capitalists!"; and they want us to be ruled by the workers and farmers in this country. Therefore, Sir, it is only by compulsory voting that we can settle it. We need a moderate and stable Government. We are going to force the middle-aged people and the middle-class to exercise their right. The right of suffrage and democracy can be preserved only through the exercise of that right. It is no use of their crying, "We want to be citizens of Singapore," and when it comes to voting they remain at home. Therefore, the new citizens and new voters of today are of vital importance and I shall term it a potential force to this country. It is only through these middle-aged and middle-class people that Singapore is as prosperous as it is today. Yet their wishes and their views are never represented in the Legislative Assembly or the City Council.

    Today, nobody dares to disregard or ignore the danger which lies ahead of us, of the great tendency of the people

Column: 1894

of Singapore who either suffer from political apathy or fall into the hands of what we call the unscrupulous politicians who lure either with power or through the mind.

    I have a newspaper cutting which shows why we need a moderate and stable government. Here is a picture in the Straits Times of 23rd December, 1958, the day after the mayoral election result was announced. Sir, I show the picture here.

    The captions read: "P.A.P. Cheers", "Clenched fists", "Victory proves people back us - Mayor," "Ong re-elected Mayor for new term." Sir, what I would like to show you are these two pictures, one showing the newly re-elected Mayor being chaired by P.A.P. supporters with clenched fists, and another one showing T. T. Rajah, with a clenched fist. I invite every hon. Member here to have a close look and study these pictures. Why are these faces so youthful? In some instances, their mouths are opened as if they were shouting during some big festival. Why cannot we get more varieties of age groups? See this picture - where are the parents, teachers and employers? Why cannot Mayor Ong Eng Guan be supported by all races, all classes and all age groups? They are not in this group here in the picture. A moderate estimate shows that the majority of them are below 25. A closer look may reveal that they are even below 20. Is this country going to be influenced by this crowd who turned up at the City Council Mayoral election? I am sure that every genuine nationalist leader here, including our People's Action Party leader, will not be satisfied if their Party were to be supported by youngsters only. They only belong to a certain group-workers, students, farmers. They are only the Chinese-speaking group.

    Sir, from this picture, the question is posed. Where was the middle-aged group who was interested in the City Council elections?

    The third reason why I am in favour of compulsory voting is that I believe compulsory voting would tend to produce a better type of candidates for election. It

Column: 1895

is only by compulsory voting that you can produce a more suitable type of candidates.

    Sir, there is a queer belief among our people in these last few years that you must vote for the Party. Do not care about the candidates. Even how unpopular the Member for Tanjong Pagar is, never mind about him. The People's Action Party is the best. Do not care for the Member for Tanjong Pagar. He is nothing. But the Party is important. There is no more individuality, but collective regimental organisation. That is the picture we are going to see. Tom and Harry can be put up as candidates for the election as long as they stand for a particular party. They do not care what kind of personality or ability they have.

    Sir, I believe that by compulsory voting, the middle-aged group and the middle class people, who are mature and experienced, will be able to give a better lead. If we can force those people to go to the polls, they will be able to influence others around them to go too. I give a particular example. If I go to the polls, my wife will naturally follow me. But if I do not go, my wife will not be bothered to go. She will say: "Even my husband does not care about voting, so why should I go to the polls?" So if I am the one who goes to the polls, I can at least bring one voter more. No matter whether or not it is decisive, we can at least cast our vote with conscience and knowledge. We will be able to know how to choose the suitable candidate that is going to represent the best interests of the people of that particular division.

    It is my belief that only by compulsory voting can we encourage persons of good character and ability, who are not interested in getting any Ministerial appointment or have any axe to grind, to reflect genuine public opinion by fearlessly speaking out their minds. This will tend to force any political Party to pick its candidates most carefully.

    The fourth reason why I am in favour of compulsory voting is that it tends to reduce corruption and malpractices. I believe that compulsory voting can at least eradicate part of the corruption and malpractices.

Column: 1896



    Let us refer for a moment to the famous Elias Commission Report. Although this Report was bitterly criticized by the People's Action Party, it has opened the eyes of the people of Singapore and made known to them how the elections are actually run, who controls them and who influences them.

    I want to relate a personal story which I experienced on my way home from abroad in a liner just two days before the Kallang by-election to the City Council. A stranger knowing that I was from Singapore, asked me, "Is it true that Singapore politics are in the hands of students and gangsters and the fight in Singapore is caused by the students and gangsters?" Sir, is it not a shame for an elected representative of Singapore to hear such stories? The stranger did not know who I was. He only knew that I was a Singaporean. Sir, it is a well-known fact that in past elections - this is actually referred to in the Elias Commission Report - undemocratic and unscrupulous elements had infiltrated into our ranks. What are we then going to do about the coming elections?

    Sir, the definition of "corruption" in the public mind is still not very clear. The act of giving two bottles of brandy or an ang pow of $100 is called corruption. Sir, that, in fact, is not true. In politics, the definition of "corruption' should include power corruption and moral corruption, besides material corruption. Let our people understand clearly in their minds that there are politicians without any morals thirsting for power. They are as equally corrupt as the gangsters in the streets. The gangsters intimidate the innocent public by the use of force. There are unscrupulous and selfish politicians who influence ignorant youngsters, workers and farmers with their irresponsible promises. Sir, these politicians are equally guilty of corruption. Sir, to those extremist politicians who know too well that Singapore will remain a Colony for some time and also that Singapore's livelihood is dependent, not only politically but also economically, on Her Majesty's pleasure, I would like to ask the Member for Sembawang who is not here, that

Column: 1897

should the Naval Base authorities decide to close down the Naval Base in Singapore, how he would be able to look after the welfare of the tens of thousands of workers who are employed in the Naval Base. Sir, I am the Member for Changi and I know how much the livelihood of the people of Changi is dependent on the Changi Airport. If because of international repercussions or Commonwealth implications Singapore cannot get its freedom, how can we promise our people unrealistic, impractical and even impossible changes to this country? Sir, I pray to God that Singapore will never have a Government with such an outlook. If I have a durian, you might say, it is shit "because Mr Lim Cher Kheng's durian must be shit". But if it was the durian of, say, the Member for Tanjong Pagar, then it would be a durian. Sir, the public may have come to believe that the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance passed by the Labour Front Coalition Government is undemocratic, but had the Ordinance been passed by the P.A.P. Government, it would have been made to appear that it would serve to bring Singapore nearer to the Federation. Sir, all these irresponsible, unrealistic and selfish political promises can be countered only by compulsory voting which will open the eyes of the people to the existence of these morally corrupt politicians. They are equally as bad as corrupt gangsters.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member is addressing the Chair and the Chair is, I think, today being very much intimidated. I would ask the hon. Member to modulate his voice and perhaps be a little calmer about the whole matter.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: I beg your pardon, Sir, I cannot help it because I am so sorry at the thought that the people of Singapore only understand the definition of corruption as merely the receiving of bottles of brandy and cash. They do not know that there is such a thing as power and moral corruption.

    Sir, I therefore strongly advocate compulsory voting because I believe that

Column: 1898

through compulsory voting we can get rid of corruption, including moral and power corruption, and malpractices. In the past, we have seen how the regimented students of a Party were ordered to get ready to start a meeting, if Mr So and So were to stand up on the stage, they clapped their hands. Only a few persons at first would start clapping their hands. Sir, you know our masses here; if a few start to clap hands, then immediately everybody starts clapping hands too. These students are regimented and well trained. The students and the workers are told, "Our Party is going to have a political meeting at a certain place." A group of people will then be given the front seats and when the leaders have spoken there is loud clapping. The reporters quickly send out this message, "This Party is very well supported. The attendance is wonderful and the Party has the genuine support of the people of Singapore." Sir, to me that is also a kind of corruption - the kind of corruption which misleads our public into believing that such and such a Party is genuinely supported and is beyond corruption. This sort of a Party is corrupted and very irresponsible.

    Sir, the last reason why I am in favour of compulsory voting is that it would stimulate the interest of the people in the elections and in political issues. Sir, if I want my children to learn, I must compel them to go to school. They will be able to concentrate and learn quickly. It is human nature that if you compel people to do anything, they will show some concern, but if you do not compel them to do anything, they will not show any concern. I will quote another practical example, Sir. Today, the Member for Tanjong Pagar, a Queen's Scholar, has to learn the Chinese language most diligently. Sir, why does the Member for Tanjong Pagar have to devote so much of his precious time to study Chinese most diligently? It is because the circumstances compel him to do so. If he wants to become a popularly supported leader of the Chinese-speaking students and workers, he must be able to speak Mandarin, Sir. Therefore, we should induce our people to be more politically conscious and to be more interested in

Column: 1899

public affairs. We must force them to understand the issues at stake in the next elections.

    Sir, in conclusion, those people who claim that compulsory voting is undemocratic, impractical and useless should bear in mind that unless compulsory voting is introduced, Singapore cannot be safe against the insidious attempt to seize power by morally corrupted extremists thirsting for power and by gangsters. It is only by compulsory voting that we can get rid of this danger. Only compulsory voting can ensure for Singapore a government which is popularly supported by and is truly representative of all races in Singapore. Singapore today needs a government with such popular support. We should never allow Singapore to fall into the hands of a government which is only supported by a section of the people - workers, farmers or any racial group. We want a government which can provide for our welfare and prosperity - a government which has the confidence of the people and which is popularly supported by all races in all age groups.

10.42 a.m.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I must rise to congratulate the Member for Changi on his most coherent and perhaps the best speech in the whole of his career in this House. Sir, I do so because I am amazed at the growth of his political maturity. I recall the time when he first crossed my path during the first general elections. He stood at the platform of my opponent in Paya Lebar Airport and there he made a speech saying, "Mr Lim Koon Teck is the Chairman of the Appeals Board in the Singapore Improvement Trust and, as Chairman, he is responsible for all the evictions." I must say that possibly the information was falsely passed to him and I bear him no malice for saying that, although at that time I had a writ ready to unseat him from this Assembly.

    Sir, those were the things which we had to face when we fought the first elections to the Legislative Assembly under the Rendel Constitution. I have been sold that political elections is a dirty

Column: 1900

game and I found, to my cost, that nothing is more dirty than that in Singapore. We who fought the elections know how much we suffered and how many home truths on corruption there are in the Elias Commission Report. So much so, Sir, that very many responsible people refuse to come forward as candidates because they are afraid to be slandered, defamed and have all the mud thrown at them on the election platform.

    The idea of compulsion in anything, particularly in using one's sacred right to vote, must be repugnant to most of us, but when we consider and reflect on what has happened during the past few elections we have had in Singapore, I think we must strike a balance and say that under no other system than the compulsory system of voting will Singapore be able to produce a truly representative government for the people of Singapore. We have seen on election day how troops of boys and young men and gangsters having all sorts of emblems tied around their foreheads, on their shirts and on their cars, rushing about from house to house telling lies sometimes to the extent that where there are old people in a house, they tell them, "You must come and vote for us," and then, when they are in the car, they are told, "Now you must vote for a certain Party and if you do not do so, we shall be able to find out for whom you voted, and dire consequences will happen to you if you do not vote for us." Sir, all these things must be stopped. We must stop the use of all cars. This costs a large sum of money and entails an obligation to the person who lends the candidate his car which sometimes gets damaged. We must, in every respect, try to make it possible so that a candidate can contest the polls without having to contravene the law by spending more than what is allowed under the Local Government Elections Ordinance.

    Sir, let us make it possible for the people of Singapore on voting day to reflect calmly, without being oppressed and without being dragged into motor cars, on the candidate whom he wants and whom he thinks will serve him best. Let us have a calm appraisal on that day and

Column: 1901

do not let us have all the hurly-burly, rough-and-tumble activities on election day as we have had during the previous years.

    On these grounds, Sir, I support compulsory voting.

10.50 a.m.

    Mr Soh Ghee Soon (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, several hon. Members of this Assembly have already expressed their views on the advantages of compulsory voting.

    I would also like to support it by pointing out that it will allow many good and honest people, who do not have much money, to stand for election since there is no more need for canvassers on polling day. Furthermore, now that Government has granted to Chinese citizens and others who have stayed here for more than eight years the right to vote, they must do so if they have the interest of the State at heart. Previously, parents with children not born in Singapore were considered aliens, no matter how long they resided here and they had no right to vote. To get naturalisation, they have had to spend a lot of money and they have had to go through a tedious procedure. Since we have given them the easy method of being Singapore citizens, we want them to participate actively in the elections.

10.52 a.m.

    Mr A. R. Lazarous (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, participation in elections to the Legislature is a privilege of democracy. Every enlightened citizen of a democratic country should know the kind of government he wants. Merely going to the polling booth does not solve the problem. He must also take a keen interest in all social and political matters. He must be able to understand the various policies that are being advocated by politicians and Parties, and he must be able to choose the personalities accordingly. Just getting a person to the polling booth is not going to solve the problem. In fact, we will be deliberately leaving the fate of the government of the country to be decided by voters who are indifferent and unenlightened.

Column: 1902



    Sir, in England - the home of parliamentary government - the machinery of elections has been in motion for the last 130 years without a break, and I am going to quote certain figures from a very keenly contested election, Sir, I am quoting from page 329 of Whitaker's Almanack. These figures I am quoting are for one whole constituency. I have heard the hon. Mr Lim Cher Kheng quoting the figures for Singapore.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member must not refer to a Member by name.

    Mr Lazarous: I am sorry, Sir. This hon. Member was quoting-

    Mr Speaker: Order. It is the Member for Changi.

    Mr Lazarous: I am sorry, Sir. The Member for Changi was quoting the number of votes which particular individuals managed to get, but that is not the correct way of going about it. Now I stood for the Farrer Park Division. There were five candidates in all and, if I remember correctly, I got over 3,700 votes out of a total of over 9,000 votes. Altogether there were over 12,000 people registered as voters for the Farrer Park Division, and 40 per cent of these 12,000 voters could never be found at all. The Members who stood for elections will agree with me that at least from 35 to 40 per cent of the voters could never be found. They were either not found at their addresses or they were found at the wrong addresses. So it would be more correct to say that the number of voters was 60 per cent of those registered. In my Ward, 70 to 75 per cent of the total number of voters went to the polls.

    I am quoting figures of the elections in England:

    Rt. Hon. Macmillan - out of 47,000 voters for the constituency, 40,000 voted.

    Rt. Hon. Gaitskell - out of 57,000 voters, 38,000 voted.

    Rt. Hon. Attlee - out of 42,000 voters 34,000 voted.

    Rt. Hon. Lennox-Boyd - out of 49,000 voters, 33,000 voted.

    Rt. Hon. Lyttleton - out of 50,000 voters, 40,000 voted.

Column: 1903



    Sir Winston Churchill - out of 72,000 voters, 62,000 voted.

When I quote "Sir Winston Churchill - out of 72,000 voters, 62,000 voted", it does not mean that 62,000 people voted for Sir Winston Churchill. It means that 62,000 people of the whole constituency went to vote. So this works out to about 60 to 70 per cent of the total number of voters who went to vote.

    Sir, we all admit that the election registers of Singapore are absolutely inaccurate. You could put it at literally 60 per cent of the voters, if you are lucky to get them. Of this 60 per cent of the voters, 70 to 75 per cent went to vote. So I do not understand how it can be said, "Ah, the people are not coming to vote. Therefore, we must have an Ordinance to compel the people to come and vote."

    Sir, in England, as I said, the election machinery has been in motion for the last 130 years, but in Singapore the elections started only from 1948. How can it be said, "The people of Singapore are just going to be indifferent. They are not enlightened. They are not intelligent enough to take part in the elections."? So when you take 60 per cent of those registered as voters to be the accurate figure due to the fact that 40 per cent of those registered as voters are untraceable, the response of the voters in Singapore is excellent comparing our election results with those of England where elections have been going on without a break for the last 130 years.

    Sir, this Government has brought up this Bill with the purpose of getting indifferent and unenlightened people to come to vote. My point is that there is no need for us to compel such people to come and vote. If you say that there are quite a number of indifferent voters in Singapore, there are also people in other countries who are equally indifferent and who do not want to vote and if you are going to compel these people to vote, there must be something wrong.

    Sir, I oppose the particular clause which compels the people to vote.

Column: 1904

    The Chief Minister rose-

    Mr Speaker: In reply?

    The Chief Minister: In reply, Sir. Mr Speaker, Sir, for 11 years have I sat in the Legislatures of this country.     Sir, when the Bill was considered in Select Committee, representations were heard from the Chambers of Commerce, the Manufacturers' Association, and certain individuals connected with manufacturing in Singapore. The main

Column: 1911

objections were jointly from the Chambers of Commerce, and the grounds for the main opposition were as follows. First, they objected to the licensing of manufacture of almost every type, because they considered that that was too rigorous a requirement and created a state of uncertainty. Secondly, they considered that the 15-year life of the licence was too short and that there was no certainty that the licences would be renewed by a different government. They also considered that the power vested in the Minister was too excessive, and that there were no checks on the Minister in the form of any machinery for appeals. They considered that there was no safeguard for those who were in the course of setting up industrial projects. And finally some of them were opposed to the granting of monopolies to any one manufacturer. These points, Sir, were considered by the Government, and amendments were moved by me in the Select Committee to remedy these main grounds of opposition.

    The amended Bill, Sir, meets this opposition by the following methods: licensing has been abolished and registration has been substituted. The 15-year period has now been removed so that registration is for an indefinite period. Manufacture of every type is now not required to be registered; instead only the manufacture of those items specified in the Schedules is required to be registered. A Registrar has been provided for to administer the requirements of the Ordinance, and an appeal to the Minister over the Registrar has been provided for. Additions and variations to the Schedules are to be made by the Minister, but an appeal to the Assembly is provided for in the form of a provision whereby the Assembly can, by a motion, overrule the Minister. Projects already set up and are manufacturing cannot be refused registration. Projects in the course of being set up are safeguarded by a provision that registration for such projects cannot be refused except for those in the Second Schedule. The granting of monopolies by the Registrar will still be possible, but will now have to be gazetted
